channel.title: Custom Mouse Spline
channel.description:
mhm, i've wrote once some custom mouse spline in 1 -2 hours, that've been tested for about 1 week without any ban, and i personally am convinced that the ban rate depends on the parameters you enter, so you actually can add this to your bot and let the user choose the spline type that he wants and view a sample of it on the scene graphs.
I'm convinced as well that however simple was that mouse spline, its not bannable ,that's been proved upon testing and logic.
If you do notice, you don't really move your mouse in a real curvey way, well it totally depends on the user and the mouse speed.So i personally have the pointer set on max speed, that will really let the mouse move in a semi-straight line on the long run, so it all depends, but the most important thing is that the algorithm of the spline shouldnt be based on one final unrandomized algorithm and that ofcourse the mouse path cant be one long straight line.
Now here is the youtube vid of how you can test it to generate random splines, but noticed that the modulus of amplitude and spacing should always be mutual and respective, and make sure that you lower the amplitude as much as possible to get a much more smooth curve.
Note: Amplitude <= 10 should make it very human like, any value above that is under your own risk. [url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6dmMge_KAjE]Click here for the vid[/url]
I'll post the application+source later on when i am on the right pc.

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:43, topic:304044”][quote author=Freddy1990 link=topic=400286.msg3059280#msg3059280 date=1260735301]
No offense, but this is ridicules, splines are rly stupid for humanlike movement, no one moves their cursor in waves, seriously, ppl move their move in straight or slightly bent lent, i some cases moving slightly past the target and going back very fast…
[/quote]as the developer of the scar rewrite, its taken you long enough to realize this[/quote]
Hmm, I never rewrote SCAR, well, until now, which is still in progress, and I’ve never actually written any mouse algorithms before, but I’m considering to for the rewrite… Currently, SCAR has Benland’s windmouse algorithm, no more splines, it comes a lot closer to reality than splines…

Read full topic

@tofurocks wrote:

Like that guy said about the PMod forums, the macro system doesn’t kick in until you’re reported. And if you’re playing legit on a tablet, you won’t get reported. So the spline detection never occured.
Just a suggestion.

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:32, topic:304044”]When the player mod forums were leaked I took the time to read them and came across this statement:
“A macro report simply activates the macro detection system, so there’s no harm. the truth, though, is that it doesn’t detect autotypers - yet - but that’s confidential pmod info, so don’t tell that to non-pmods.” - from memory, the topic was about people spamming at the grand exchange (spam advertising of pump and dump clans to be precise).

One of the biggest issues with runescape is that all of the younger players would like to become player moderators and are therefore on the lookout for the less-than-savvy botter to report.
This is probably more to blame for people getting caught than any single flaw in the botting software.

I think lawl is right in saying that the mouse data movement information isn’t that big of an issue. It boils down, in my opinion, to ‘fitting in’ with the surroundings. What are the odds that someone would report you while you were training herblore at the GE on a level 90+ account? Compare that to the odds that you would be reported for mining essence on a f2p world with a level 3.
The same can be said for alching at the GE compared with alching in some out of the way spot, such as the magic guild. Why would someone alch at the magic guild for hours on end? Could it be that they’re hiding so that they can automate the skill without repercussions? I’d better report them, just in case.

Realistically, they’re a company of less than 500 with millions of active players; there’s only so much analysis that they can perform on everyone; the rest would be optional analysis (which, in this case, is triggered by the use of the report system by another player).[/quote]Is there still an archive around of the leaked PMod threads? Would someone care to PM it to me?

Read full topic

Lothy, the way you explained that, it sounds like an auto-responder would be 100x more useful than a new mouse spline and stuff. If you talk back and it’s a good, randomized response, they will think twice before reporting you.

Read full topic

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @Kosaki Kosaki
item.description:
@Kosaki wrote:

I personally doubt they use the mouse motion to anything. It is simply a waste of resources if people should watch and determine if mouse motions are generated by a bot.

Neither can the splines be replicated server side without brute forcing parameters if the spline generation method is truly random. The only thing I can think of is the time between each event, and checking mouseEntered and mouseExited events. IIRC RSBot did not call these events?

Read full topic

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

When the player mod forums were leaked I took the time to read them and came across this statement:
“A macro report simply activates the macro detection system, so there’s no harm. the truth, though, is that it doesn’t detect autotypers - yet - but that’s confidential pmod info, so don’t tell that to non-pmods.” - from memory, the topic was about people spamming at the grand exchange (spam advertising of pump and dump clans to be precise).

One of the biggest issues with runescape is that all of the younger players would like to become player moderators and are therefore on the lookout for the less-than-savvy botter to report.
This is probably more to blame for people getting caught than any single flaw in the botting software.

I think lawl is right in saying that the mouse data movement information isn’t that big of an issue. It boils down, in my opinion, to ‘fitting in’ with the surroundings. What are the odds that someone would report you while you were training herblore at the GE on a level 90+ account? Compare that to the odds that you would be reported for mining essence on a f2p world with a level 3.
The same can be said for alching at the GE compared with alching in some out of the way spot, such as the magic guild. Why would someone alch at the magic guild for hours on end? Could it be that they’re hiding so that they can automate the skill without repercussions? I’d better report them, just in case.

Realistically, they’re a company of less than 500 with millions of active players; there’s only so much analysis that they can perform on everyone; the rest would be optional analysis (which, in this case, is triggered by the use of the report system by another player).

Read full topic

regardless, the vast majority of users aren’t going to be using touch screens, so it would be easy for jagex to flag everyone who’s mouse jumps across the screen consistently, then inspect further to determine likely bots.[/quote]

I remember a discussion about tablets too, but I have never had one so I have yet to test and see exactly what mouse events are being generated, as far as I know the computer could generate mouse move events from one point to another, can’t really tell without something to test on.

Read full topic

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“mikehershey, post:24, topic:304044”]I was thinking… what about when someone uses a tablet pc? My friend uses a tablet and plays runescape all the time without getting banned. When you touch the pen somewhere on the screen it just teleports your mouse there. I only play with a drawing pad, so my mouse teleports all the time. Maybe you can get away with pretending to be a tablet pc lol? This is what my bot is gonna do (it also doesnt load parameters from rs website :P)
But seriously if tablet pc users don’t get banned mouse input can’t be that important. They probably just use it to flag you or something? I would think lots of people use tablet pc’s or drawing pads and it would take a lot of resources to flag everyone so maybe they detect your input style and dont flag tablet pcs to save their resources. Maybe you can trick it into thinking you are playing with a drawing pad or tablet pc.[/quote]

I was thinking the same thing myself. On a touchpad that is single touch, you can use two fingers to make the mouse jump all over the place. I really have no more theories of what Jagex does to detect inhuman mouse movements. Maybe they don’t even try to detect them.

Read full topic

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @mikehershey mikehershey
item.description:
@mikehershey wrote:

I was thinking… what about when someone uses a tablet pc? My friend uses a tablet and plays runescape all the time without getting banned. When you touch the pen somewhere on the screen it just teleports your mouse there. I only play with a drawing pad, so my mouse teleports all the time. Maybe you can get away with pretending to be a tablet pc lol? This is what my bot is gonna do (it also doesnt load parameters from rs website :P)
But seriously if tablet pc users don’t get banned mouse input can’t be that important. They probably just use it to flag you or something? I would think lots of people use tablet pc’s or drawing pads and it would take a lot of resources to flag everyone so maybe they detect your input style and dont flag tablet pcs to save their resources. Maybe you can trick it into thinking you are playing with a drawing pad or tablet pc.

Read full topic

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @Kosaki Kosaki
item.description:
@Kosaki wrote:

At my computer the time between each mouseMoved event was 8 ms. This was an average over 30 seconds of moving the mouse fast around. It is the same for going slower, but obviously ifyou go too slow it will be longer between each mouse event.

I assume its the same with MouseDragged events…

KBot PRO’s mouse uses splines to generate magnification points. Each point has a random magnification level and the end point (target) has a big magnification which gets smaller the closer you get. The mouse then follows the splines major curves, but does rarely follow the spline. The mouse randomly do a drop effect as well (simulating lifting the mouse and replacing it another place on the mouse pad).

I still use bezier splines for this. The start point remains the same but the end point can move under mouse move. The bot can therefor follow/hover over a moving object in game

If you guys mind to check your delay between mouse events you guys can use this source.

import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.KeyListener;
import java.awt.event.KeyEvent;
import java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener;
import java.awt.event.MouseEvent;
import javax.swing.*;
import org.jdesktop.layout.*;
import org.jdesktop.layout.GroupLayout;
import org.jdesktop.layout.LayoutStyle;
/*
 * Created by JFormDesigner on Fri Sep 25 13:34:05 CEST 2009
 */



/**
 * @author Jan Ove
 */
public class TestMouse extends JFrame {

    public boolean record = false;
    public long startTime = 0L;
    public int points = 0;
    public TestMouse() {
        initComponents();
        this.addKeyListener(new KeyListener() {
            public void keyTyped(KeyEvent e) {
               if(e.getKeyChar()=='1'){
                   record = true;
                   startTime = System.currentTimeMillis();

               }
                else if(e.getKeyChar()=='2'){
                   record = false;
                   startTime = 0L;
                   points = 0;
               }
            }

            public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) {
                //To change body of implemented methods use File | Settings | File Templates.
            }

            public void keyReleased(KeyEvent e) {
                //To change body of implemented methods use File | Settings | File Templates.
            }
        });
        this.addMouseMotionListener(new MouseMotionListener() {
            public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) {
                //To change body of implemented methods use File | Settings | File Templates.
            }

            public void mouseMoved(MouseEvent e) {
                if(record){
                    points++;
                    long time = System.currentTimeMillis()-startTime;
                    timeLabel.setText(""+(time/points)+" ms.");
                }
            }
        });
    }

    public static void main(String[] args){
        new TestMouse().setVisible(true);
    }

    private void initComponents() {
        // JFormDesigner - Component initialization - DO NOT MODIFY  //GEN-BEGIN:initComponents
        label1 = new JLabel();
        label2 = new JLabel();
        label3 = new JLabel();
        timeLabel = new JLabel();

        //======== this ========
        setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        Container contentPane = getContentPane();
        contentPane.setLayout(null);

        //---- label1 ----
        label1.setText("Average time:");
        contentPane.add(label1);
        label1.setBounds(new Rectangle(new Point(6, 6), label1.getPreferredSize()));

        //---- label2 ----
        label2.setText("To start click 1");
        contentPane.add(label2);
        label2.setBounds(new Rectangle(new Point(6, 26), label2.getPreferredSize()));

        //---- label3 ----
        label3.setText("To stop click 2");
        contentPane.add(label3);
        label3.setBounds(new Rectangle(new Point(6, 46), label3.getPreferredSize()));

        //---- timeLabel ----
        timeLabel.setText("time label");
        contentPane.add(timeLabel);
        timeLabel.setBounds(new Rectangle(new Point(92, 6), timeLabel.getPreferredSize()));

        { // compute preferred size
            Dimension preferredSize = new Dimension();
            for(int i = 0; i < contentPane.getComponentCount(); i++) {
                Rectangle bounds = contentPane.getComponent(i).getBounds();
                preferredSize.width = Math.max(bounds.x + bounds.width, preferredSize.width);
                preferredSize.height = Math.max(bounds.y + bounds.height, preferredSize.height);
            }
            Insets insets = contentPane.getInsets();
            preferredSize.width += insets.right;
            preferredSize.height += insets.bottom;
            contentPane.setMinimumSize(preferredSize);
            contentPane.setPreferredSize(preferredSize);
        }
        setSize(785, 530);
        setLocationRelativeTo(getOwner());
        // JFormDesigner - End of component initialization  //GEN-END:initComponents
    }

    // JFormDesigner - Variables declaration - DO NOT MODIFY  //GEN-BEGIN:variables
    private JLabel label1;
    private JLabel label2;
    private JLabel label3;
    private JLabel timeLabel;
    // JFormDesigner - End of variables declaration  //GEN-END:variables
}

Read full topic

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:20, topic:304044”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=400286.msg2969172#msg2969172 date=1253834692]
dont peopel realize that it only receives mouse movements every 50 or so ms? a lot of points are missed so really it doesnt matter much…
[/quote]cant this be another thing they look for? all of the points being received exactly the way they are supposed to and not missing any = bot[/quote]
RSBot generates the spline then throws away most of the points. I think it does one point every x ms then the spaces between define the speed.

Read full topic

item.title: Custom Mouse Spline
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Tenac, I think you’re wrong. There’s also no way you can predict/impersonate human like mouse movements. A neural network style approach may be conceivable. You play the game for an hour or so, which ‘trains’ or ‘teaches’ the network, the network then takes over. It could load/save these settings, and maybe even be recording in the background all the time.

Denver you’re an absolute idiot. Don’t tell me I don’t know what i’m talking about.
[/quote]this is pretty much the best way

wasnt mopar going to put it this in his client[/quote]

I am still going to.
